Posts.Content: Hi Toxopholite. I certainly didn't mean to scare you my dear. Hopefully this will pass. I will try massage. Maybe it is the skin around the implant contracting as you say. I've left a message for my BCN asking for some advice. We'll see how it goes. Chin up and on we go!! Xx
Posts.Title: Tightness in implant area after radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi all.  Hope you are keeping well.  Have my final of 25 radiotherapy sessions tomorrow. Yey!! Anyway, just over the last few days a tightness under my arm and in the chest area where the implant is has developed. It has become really quite uncomfortable. Does it go away in time do we know?  I'm imagining the implant like a plastic dish that you put in the microwave which shrivels up if left in for too long. These never go back to shape and I'm wondering if the implant will be the same or will it relax in time? I'm not sure I'll be able to stand it if it's like this forever.  Thanks as always for any advice. Xx
Posts.Title: Tightness in implant area after radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi there. I too have developed phlebitis after my 2nd chemo. Or tracking I heard the nurses call it. It can be quite unpleasant. Some advise massaging the area whilst I read in other places it was not advisable to so I didn't. Instead I have been using hemp oil and ibuprofen cream on the area twice a day. It hasn't resolved the hardness of the veins but helps with the soreness and cording that goes with it.  Perhaps worth a try for you. And it won't be permanent that's the main thing. Your veins will recover once the chemos all finished.  Good luck! X
Posts.Title: FECing Veins!

Posts.Content: Hi Rosethorn.  Hope you're doing ok. I've used this for deworming and defleaing my cat. It can be used internally and topically to clean parasites from your intestines and colon. A healthy gut and colon is essential to keeping your immune system working as well as possible through all we're going through. If your system is clean and healthy there are fewer demands on your immune system.  There are easier things to source than diatemacious earth that you can use though and it is quite expensive. My daily regime includes aloe vera colon cleanse tabs (easily got from H&B), I take Apple Cider Vinegar every day (raw organic unpasteurised ACV with the mother - great for loads of stuff - helps with sickliness, colon cleanser, helps alkalinity, use it on skin for eczema, put on cold sores, all sorts), milkthistle for helping the liver cope with the chemo, supergreens drink every day to boost your pre and pro biotic flora and I even went to the lengths of having a full reverse osmosis water filtration system fitted (6 stage) so it takes all the harmful stuff out of the water such as metals, pesticides, fluoride, parasites (yes parasites) and that's just to mention the nicer things that we can find in our drinking water. The 6th filter then puts back in all the good minerals like phosphorus, zinc, selenuim, etc. It's been a worthwhile and not that costly an exercise which I think is helping me cope with the chemo well. From all the reading I've done, to give your body the support it needs to survive I estimate for my own part the most important 3 things I've done are:- *Cut done on refined sugars and processed foods * Boost your immunity with some of the measures above.  * Eat alkaline foods to boost your body's alkalinity. These things seem to work for me so thought I'd share just as some extra food for thought. X
Posts.Title: diatomaceous earth

Posts.Content: Hi K.  The discomfort can be horrible I know. For pain relief I couldn't fault Tramadol. I was told by the BCN that it was fine to take it with some paracetamol too for a good hit of pain relief.  For sleeping I used and still use Valerian. You can get it from Holland and Barrett. Plant based so no extra chemicals for your body to absorb. Just a very earth smell to get used to! And for comfort while trying to sleep.... since breaking my leg two years ago I still use a large pillow to put my legs up on but more crucially I still have (can't seem to sleep without it now!) a nice soft pillow under my left side. I invested in some extra soft pillows for my head too (have a funny head too!) You can prop your sore bits up on the soft pillows. I found it helped immensely. Under my left arm is still quite tender at times and find it difficult still to lay on my right side with my left arm resting on my side. But that will pass in time I'm sure.  Hope your Mum finds some relief with something.  Xx
Posts.Title: Any tips on ways to get some sleep after lumpectomy?

Posts.Content: Good evening lovely ladies.  I hope it's not inappropriate to do this but I was just wondering how anyone else is feeling after 3rd chemo ECT, in particular, but after any if you wanna talk about it. Starting Taxotere on Friday for the last 3 of 6. Mixed reports about side effects of this. Any experiences? X
Posts.Title: Just feeling a bit jaded!

Posts.Content: Hi there, Positive and negative notes I'm afraid. On the negative, I am currently feeling extremely low and washed out. I thought it was a hangover from a bit of a heavy weekend! But it's now Tuesday and that was Saturday. I finished chemo in January and rads in April. It hits you at times.  On the positive - these instances are few and far between and seem to get less and less. It has been ages and ages since I felt like this. Maybe it's just general fatigue due to going back to work and not sticking as rigidly to my supergreens and smoothies as I was.  It will get better and you will start feeling better. I still feel like having a good cry sometimes and why not? A good cry can be as therapeutic as a good laugh at times. Just take one day at a time and take all the support that is offered. It will get better.  Hugs xx
Posts.Title: Post Chemo - when will I start feeling better?

Posts.Content: Good evening all.  Hope you are all keeping warm and well.  It's been 2 weeks since having my final of 6 chemo sessions and am feeling so inactive and out of condition that I've never felt so out of condition. I know you shouldn't run before you can walk but was wondering if people would recommend returning to swimming at this stage?  Also it's been 8 months since my mastectomy and implant operation. Even now though under my arm slightly further down it is still very sensitive. Sometimes it is still difficult to sleep on that side and still default to sleeping on my back or right hand side. My outer arm at the top near my shoulder is still quite numb. Very odd when I have an itch there as there is little or no sensation when I try to scratch it.  Thanks for any comments. X
Posts.Title: Getting back to exercise. And underarm sensitivity.

Posts.Content: It is especially when you don't get the feeling of the itch being sated. Grrr.
Posts.Title: Getting back to exercise. And underarm sensitivity.

Posts.Content: Hi there Fiddlercrab.  Yes it is only 2 weeks tomorrow since I had my final chemo dose. Maybe you're right and waiting a little while would be prudent. Just feeling so lazy. Thought if I ask them if I can wear some of those rubber swimming pumps so feet don't touch the floor and take my dettol spray and hand gel, I might get away with it. But probably best to err on the side of caution. X
Posts.Title: Getting back to exercise. And underarm sensitivity.

Posts.Content: Hi Julia. Thanks for that. The numbness and sensitivity underarm is annoyng but in the grand scheme of things it could be a lot worse. We just have to be patient! Hmmmm... Xx
Posts.Title: Getting back to exercise. And underarm sensitivity.

Posts.Content: Sorry and AnnCG. Xx
Posts.Title: Post Chemo Fatigue and Hair!

Posts.Content: Hi Julia. Thanks for your reply. To answer your question by fatigue I mean for example the day before yesterday I did some packing in the kitchen as we have to move in two weeks (right at the start of radiotherapy-bad timing or what - hey ho) and that bit of packing and lifting boxes left me feeling wiped out yesterday. You feel good for the exercise initially but it wipes you out later on.  I think I'm going to return to swimming though very soon and the new tai chi classes will help a lot I think. You've certainly been through the wars too. Leaving it all behind, as you say, once treatment is finished is no mean feat either but I suppose the further behind it is the easier you can pick up the threads of your life again.  Take care. Xx
Posts.Title: Post Chemo Fatigue and Hair!

Posts.Content: Good afternoon. Hope we're all warm and keeping well.  Three weeks post chemo and just wondering when this insipid fatigue will start to clear and I'll start feeling like my old self again. What are your experiences please?  Also, I had the cold cap treatment but obviously still lost a bit of hair and still am losing a bit each day but now post chemo I'm wondering when the hair will stop coming out and start growing back?  Thanks all.  Xx
Posts.Title: Post Chemo Fatigue and Hair!

Posts.Content: Thank you so much Tracy, Momo and Julia (and any other replies I might have missed). The general concensus is that some patience on my side is in order!   You just want to get back to normal that's the thing but, as you've all rightly said, it takes time.  Well am all sleepy headed again so off to bed.  Goodnight and take care of yourselves. Thanks again ladies. Amanda. Xx
Posts.Title: Post Chemo Fatigue and Hair!

Posts.Content: Morning all.  Hope you are keeping warm and well.  Had the Docetaxel for the first time of three last Friday. Had 3 sessions previously of EC. So now had four of six sessions of chemo. So surprised, as I coped really well with the EC, that the Docetaxel has knocked me flat. The main problem is aching muscles and joints everywhere. Like having the flu. It's been a week now though and was expecting it to start subsiding by now. Have virtually spent the week in bed with tramadol for the pain. No other real problems apart from that gladly though. Getting quite severe pain under my ribcage at times where my liver is. What are other peoples experiences of this? When did your symptoms start to subside?  Sorry I feel like I only come on here to moan but it helps to know what length of time this might last.  Thanks. Least it's Friday!  My works do today but not up to going. Amanda. X
Posts.Title: Docetaxel Side Effects

Posts.Content: Hi Julia. Thanks for replying.  I haven't been out in a week so need to try and get out for a walk. I think I'll try and go for an hour later. Just get dosed up about 4pm then should be good for a few hours.  Am drinking tons of water so that should be helping the old liver function.   Might be my imagination but am feeling slightly more lively today. Here's hoping. Oh and hot flushes!!! Never known anything like this. But hot flushes are the least of our worries eh? Hope you have a good weekend Julia. Amanda. X
Posts.Title: Docetaxel Side Effects

Posts.Content: Morning.  Like everyone is saying everyone 's reaction is different and personal but you seem to have nailed it!  Chuffed for you. I'm feeling much better in the last couple of days. No pain killers for two days now. So I think the worst is over. We'll see how the next two go but at least now I know what to expect.  Have a lovely Christmas. Xx
Posts.Title: Docetaxel Side Effects

Posts.Content: Hi Karra. Oh bless you. You really have been through it. But you got there. Hope I get through the rest of it relarively unscathed. Feeling better in the last two days now and no pain relief needed now so I hope that's the worst over and just two more to deal with now.  Look after yourself. Merry Christmas. Xx
Posts.Title: Docetaxel Side Effects

Posts.Content: Hi hun. Thanks for your comments. The effects seem to have eased now thank heavens. Still little bits of joint pain here and there but haven't needed pain relief for two days now so the worst is over I think. Phew! At least getting the first one over you know what to expect next time around so I'll be ready. Only two more.  Have a great Christmas. Xx
Posts.Title: Docetaxel Side Effects

Posts.Content: Oh bless you I bet that was a huge relief. Just keep working away at it and staying positive is a big factor I find. Have a great Christmas and look after yourself. Xx
Posts.Title: Docetaxel Side Effects

Posts.Content: Morning Jo. Had the T on the Friday, was fine Saturday but it floored me come Sunday. That has lasted until this Saturday just gone (so a whole week) when I had the last lot of pain relief. Feeling pretty okay now but get tired easily cleaning up and that.  Apart from the joint pain, you feel very tired and the hot flushes are becoming very annoying! But happily apart from that the effects have been minimal. But like everyone keeps saying though each person's reaction is different but I hope yours are minimal too. I credit that though to taking a host of organic supplements such as turmeric, coconut oil, aloe vera and milkthistle to protect the liver. I also take Bioglan Supergreens every day and have a packed smoothie every day. (They were a bit hard to get down when I was off it though  ).  I hope you'll be fine with it Jo. Keep me posted how you're doing. Scary but will soon be over. Amanda. Xx
Posts.Title: Docetaxel Side Effects

Posts.Content: Hi Carolyn.  Hi Carolyn, This Docetaxel stuff seems to debilitate everyone in some way or another doesnt it. The feet and shin burning sounds horrible. Bless you.  The tramadol works great but you just end up feeling sleepy all the time. Not feeling too bad now I'm dosed up and can quite imagine getting dressed and going in for an hour later. But then it wears off and drops you flat again. I may try and go for an hour later. Drinking tons of water to flush the system out so hopefully that's helping.  You take care and thanks. Amanda.  I have some soreness in the
Posts.Title: Docetaxel Side Effects
